A majority of New York City voters would support a law allowing gay marriage, according to a poll released Thursday.
 But by a slim margin, they also back Mayor Michael Bloomberg's decision to appeal a recent court ruling supporting same-sex unions, the Quinnipiac University Poll found.
 
 In the poll, 51 percent of respondents said they favored legalizing gay marriage, while 40 percent were opposed. White voters were much more likely to back the law than black voters - 61 percent of whites wanted the law, compared with just 36 percent of blacks.
 
 "There's a big split between black and white voters over gay marriage," said Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute. 
 
 By a margin of 49 to 44 percent, voters said they agreed with Bloomberg's strategy of appealing a state Supreme Court decision last month that the state's refusal to grant marriage licenses to gays was unconstitutional.
 
 Bloomberg has said he personally supports gay marriage but wants to test the court ruling to avoid the "chaos" San Francisco experienced last year when it issued marriage licenses to same-sex couples. The marriages were later ruled invalid.
 
 The poll surveyed 1,435 New York City registered voters between February 22 and March 1. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.6 percentage points.

 Progressive income taxes, although in a sense attack equality, also defend equality. Furthermore, progressive income taxes defend happiness, in a sense. Allow me to explain: progressive income taxes, although on the surface take more money from one man than the next, they help protect the concept of one man making less money than the next for putting in the same amount of work. We cannot all be successful business men or billionaires, no matter how hard we may work or try at it, and those who fail often fail because of bad luck or simply not being smart enough. This does not mean they deserve less money. If we can help these people while still preserving the draw of capitalism, then we should do so; they have worked just as hard. Now, progressive taxes do not attack this problem as directly as they could because they are more focused on happiness. The simple truth is that taking more money from people who have more money does not hurt the happiness and livability of those people as much as it would hurt those with less money. Finally, on an economic level, a flat income tax reduces the demand of the lower and middle class citizens on the market and creates excessive demand of the upper class, who have a lot of money to spend. This can result in too much development aimed toward the super-rich instead of the average person, and may eventually hurt the standard of living for us all.
 
 As for hate laws, well that is not a matter of treating people differently under the law, it is a matter of punishing different motives for crimes differently. If one person murders a man in self defense, another murders a man in a heated rage because his wife was cheating with that man, and another murders a man because he is an African American, then the third deserves the worst punishment. The third man has committed the crime with the most malicious and evil intent, and the third man is the most dangerous to put back on the street.
